Light in August:
>They have thundered past now and crashed silently on into the dusk; night has fully come. Yet he still sits at the study window, the room still dark behind him. The street lamp at the corner flickers and glares, so that the bitten shadows of the unwinded maples seem to toss faintly upon the August darkness. From a distance, quite faint though quite clear, he can hear the sonorous waves of massed voices from the church: a sound at once austere and rich, abject and proud, swelling and falling in the quiet summer darkness like a harmonic tide.
>Then he sees a man approaching along the street. On a week night he would have recognised the figure, the shape, the carriage and gait. But on Sunday evening, and with the echo of the phantom hooves still crashing soundlessly in the duskfilled study, he watches quietly the puny, unhorsed figure moving with that precarious and meretricious cleverness of animals balanced on their hinder legs; that cleverness of which the man animal is so fatuously proud and which constantly betrays him by means of natural laws like gravity and ice, and by the very extraneous objects which he has himself invented, like motor cars and furniture in the dark, and the very refuse of his own eating left upon floor or pavement; and he thinks quietly how right the ancients were in making the horse an attribute and symbol of warriors and kings, when he sees the man in the street pass the low sign and turn into his gate and approach the house. He sits forward then, watching the man come up the dark walk toward the dark door; he hears the man stumble heavily at the dark bottom step. “Byron Bunch,” he says. “In town on Sunday night. Byron Bunch in town on Sunday.”

>>21370285
>he can't tell the difference between these styles
I must say, if you present these two as similar you have the literary equivalent of tone-deafness, in my humble opinion.

How would you say this observant walk through a building, almost clinical in its detail, is in any way similar beyond "a simple knack for writing" to the at worst melodramatic use of an environment to present a sort of mood? The Faulkner is one breathless whispering of a man's observation of his surroundings in their relation to himself, whereas Nabokov's stretch is an almost irreverent and comical observation of the bibelots contained in some manse, cut into by parentheses, asides, and in a way, a sort of miniature tour. The Faulkner, again, has a texture of emotion infused into every string, whilst Nabokov keeps a sort of academic distance. Take the description of the trees in either example, Faulkner's trees are an environmental effect, part of a shadow cast by an unsteady and harsh light, he uses his trees to paint a picture, but one with "bitten shadows", "unwinded maples", nothing is without its verbal ally to prop it up, whilst Nabokov's tree is similarly describing a shadow cast by a tree but in a very different manner, clinical to the detail, what tree it is, what type of shadow it is casting (large leaf, contrast that with bitten, nabokov enters into detail to describe almost stubbornly that this tree has a leafy shadow, big surprise) even a lengthy, texture-of-text upheaving aside from Ada to describe the root of this tree in name.

No, their styles do not mix, perhaps at a certain superficial perspective, but from where I sit (not, perhaps, very far from the surface) there are distinct examples of these two authors being worlds apart in what and how they use their language, how they build their sentences, to what extent they describe what they do, the pace, the amount of emotion that is allowed to seep from the author themselves, and the colors they use (namely, that faulkner doesn't use any, whilst nabokov uses at least one within the first sentence of the excerpt to "fill in" the blanks). Perhaps a possible notable similarity is that they both use sentences. Which isn't exactly a glaring example of stylistic kinship.

Nabokov is a jokester, he breaks Ada winding monologues with Van's comical off chance remarks. The tedious spatial descriptions are peppered with old Van's wit (tonguetied Ada, intolerably bored Van, Van's burning bladder) not only does it convey the awkwardness of first encounters, all the unimportant chatter and silent observation, but by it's contrast defines both characters. Pragmatic Van, cynically twisting his memories to rewrite the past (the only emotion in the scene is retroactively written in by small comments) and "innocent", pretentious Ada. The key here is Nabokov's sense of humor, wordplay and comic timing.

>>21370858
>Anything that intimates a higher meaning behind the world of appearances (Faulkner, Conrad, Bellow) he rejected. His stories take place in a materialist world full of colours and textures but without transcendence, the universe to him was a beautiful and cruel arrangement of coincidences.
He did indeed criticize authors for “pasting up a cardboard Christ in the story to give it meaning,” but a work like Pale Fire, for instance, is precisely at its core about questions like life-after-death, synchronicities, parapsychology and the like (even if they’re regarded wryly, subversively, satirically and in a postmodern fashion, with reversals and blunders which deflate seeming supernatural occurrences).

See the message Hazel gets from a “dancing light” in the barnyard:

pada ata lane pad not ogo old wart alan ther tale feur far rant lant tal told

The book doesn’t explain this message (Kinbote is unable to make sense of it), but Nabokov himself translated it in a letter after the novel’s publication. When read aloud, the message loosely sounds like an instruction for father not to cross the lane to the Goldsworth house to hear a tale of a foreign land—read this way, the light relaying the message knows the fate that awaits Hazel’s father (he gets shot after crossing the street to Kinbote’s house, which Judge Goldsworth owns).

I know you're baiting but he said the element of time doesn't matter when you're writing a novel; the author should have every single scenario and scene already worked out in his head before pen ever touches paper. Also Nabby didn't write his novels in sequential order; he liked to jump around and write whatever scene was most interesting at the time, and he did this on index cards so he could shuffle them around and lay them out in different orders and fill in the missing spots as needed.

>The verbal starkness that so often muddily refers back to some primitive or biblical/spiritual meaning is just a disguise for a lack of technical and unacademic rigor.
It doesn't refer to any primitive or biblical spiritual meaning actually. You were just filtered. He makes it clear repeatedly. The suggestion in McCarthy's metaphor is an important part of how narrative is made, but it is always dissociative, referring to something that doesn't readily resolves into a coherent narrative. Pressure of meaning David Holloway called it. This is even explicitly referenced in Blood Meridian. When The Judge and the idiot are being alluded to as King Lear and Fool:
>It was the judge and the imbecile. They were both of them naked and they neared through the desert dawn like beings of a mode little more than tangential to the world at large, their figures now quick with clarity and now fugitive in the strangeness of that same light. Like things whose very portent renders them ambiguous. Like things so charged with meaning that their forms are dimmed.
Their true forms (the judge and the idiot) have "become dimmed" in favor of the associative suggestions of metaphor (charged with meaning; king lear and fool here, a few more iirc). Similar meta suggestions are sprinkled all across BM, and is McCarthy's true philosophy. In kekule problem he said:
>the world is only made of facts, it is us who channel it into a narrative.
Or something to that accord. That is very much McCarthy's mode in BM. A laconic clinical description of physical world with sudden flights into associative imagery. BM is in the truest sense about the process of meaning-making and not any greater spiritual transcendence beyond the veener of reality (which is why there is absolutely no agreed upon interpretation of the book, a la Pale fire somewhat but McCarthy doesn't have to rely on obvious parlor tricks)
>a vague impression of the author's tone that even HE would struggle to clarify in any way
I think you greatly overvalue your intelligence. Those with enough cognitive intelligence can see what McCarthy is trying to do. You trying to suggest that because you couldn't make head or tail of it somehow means that even the author wouldn't is a dumb as hell claim to make. This is also the problem I think, McCarthy unlike other writers, Nabokov included requires cognition to appreciate. No amount of reference or trivia (no hazel trees?) hunting will make readers see his greater aesthetic. And its funny you call Nabokov a scientist when McCarthy's aesthetic is far more "scientific" inasmuch it serves a deep vision of the world which, even if we make concessions for Nabokov's hidden spirituality and philosophy of creation, is frankly on a completely different level to what Vladdy is trying to sell his audience. Ironically, the philosophers in his books argue against a transcendent view of reality, for the people who mistakenly think he is in the same vein as Dostoevsky or Faulkner.

I'm not saying that Faulkner is as good a poet as Shakespeare, or that his poetic style is similar to Shakespeare's, but I can't understand how Nabokov sees as flaws in Faulkner's work things that he praises in Shakespeare.

>Bombastic language
>Impossible dialogues
>extravagant “deep” conversations
>combination of starkness and hyperbole

All this is found in all of Shakespeare's plays. Language is never natural, dialogues are always "impossible" because human beings don't speak that way. Shakespeare's "deep thoughts" are often commonplaces that have been repeated thousands of times, but which Shakespeare is now repeating in what is perhaps the most beautiful poetic language ever created (although it remains "extravagant 'deep' conversations" nonetheless). The bombast happens in every play, so much so that if Shakespeare becomes interested in a particular topic or image, he forgets the play and the character that is speaking and gets more concerned with writing great poetry than creating a "mimesis" of the world.

I can understand Nabokov saying that he fails to consider Faulkner's language great poetry, but only the attempts of a pseudo-poet trying to write great poetry. But the criticisms of artificiality, of bombast, of pretentiousness, of exaggeration: this is all exactly the same as what we find in Shakespeare.

Not just Shakespeare. Nabokov liked Moby-Dick, and the same criticisms he leveled at Faulkner can be leveled at Melville. Perhaps in this case the difference is that he likes Melville's poetry but not Faulkner's.

>>21370285
>behind him seem to from a distance faint clear he can hear a sound he sees he would have recognised the echo of soundlessly he watches quietly when he sees he sits watching he hears
Nabokov wouldn't use these words. He's willing to be direct.
Faulkner wants you to know that this here is the observer, those are his observations, and all the way over there you have reality. It wouldn't do to get them confused!
Nabokov homes straight in on qualic memory. He isn't going to say that Van looked at the tree that Ada showed him, or that the tree's leaves' shadows seem large to him. We know it's Van and we know that he's being given a tour. Calling the shadows large would be more than sufficient, and what you really want to explain is how the leaves overlap the threshold, because that's the sort of detail that sticks in your memory. The rest is implied.
This is very deliberate, not just for this novel (a fake autobiography of sorts) but in general. In pic related (from http://www.kafka.org/index.php?id=191,209,0,0,1,0) he claims that so-called "objective reality" doesn't even exist. It's not so strange that he'd be turned off by somebody who goes in the other direction.

Let's discuss the works and ideas of Alexis de Tocqueville.
Post your favorite passages, quotes, etc.

“What good does it do me, after all, if an ever-watchful authority keeps an eye out to ensure that my pleasures will be tranquil and races ahead of me to ward off all danger, sparing me the need even to think about such things, if that authority, even as it removes the smallest thorns from my path, is also absolute master of my liberty and my life; if it monopolizes vitality and existence to such a degree that when it languishes, everything around it must also languish; when it sleeps, everything must also sleep; and when it dies, everything must also perish?

There are some nations in Europe whose inhabitants think of themselves in a sense as colonists, indifferent to the fate of the place they live in. The greatest changes occur in their country without their cooperation. They are not even aware of precisely what has taken place. They suspect it; they have heard of the event by chance. More than that, they are unconcerned with the fortunes of their village, the safety of their streets, the fate of their church and its vestry. They think that such things have nothing to do with them, that they belong to a powerful stranger called “the government.” They enjoy these goods as tenants, without a sense of ownership, and never give a thought to how they might be improved. They are so divorced from their own interests that even when their own security and that of their children is finally compromised, they do not seek to avert the danger themselves but cross their arms and wait for the nation as a whole to come to their aid. Yet as utterly as they sacrifice their own free will, they are no fonder of obedience than anyone else. They submit, it is true, to the whims of a clerk, but no sooner is force removed than they are glad to defy the law as a defeated enemy. Thus one finds them ever wavering between servitude and license.

When a nation has reached this point, it must either change its laws and mores or perish, for the well of public virtue has run dry: in such a place one no longer finds citizens but only subjects.”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21366821
It's the hours. I'm a student, but I'm going to try and get a comfy government job through a little bit of nepotism. If I could work in a firm for flat 40 hours a week and leave it at the door, I would do it. However, that's usually insurance law which doesn't really pay that much. Everything else is incredibly deadline intensive, and the clients want work done yesterday.

Also, the biggest problem with the practice of law is the billable hour. Firms might set you a target that says you need 1800 billable hours a year. You might think 'woo, nice, that's the same as the average hours worked by US employees, and lawyers get paid a lot so it's fine.' It's not fine. Just because you have been at work for an hour does not mean that's a billable hour. It's entirely common to be at work for 8 hours but only bill 5, in which case you either BILL for 11 (work for 14+) the next day to catch catch up, or more commonly work on the weekend to make up those extra unbilled hours.

Also, 1800 hours is not a common target for big firms. Firms that pay a decent wage relative to hours worked demand 2100+ billable hours a year. Which factoring in commute and all this shit means you have been 'at work' for 3000+. There's a very good paper about this if you want to know more about why never to work for a law firm.

https://law.yale.edu/sites/default/files/area/department/cdo/document/billable_hour.pdf

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21368316
Depends. Questions like yours are why constitutional law is its own field. Interpretations vary. For example, there was another case of a guy who stole mail. The court decided that an appropriate punishment was to make him stand out in public holding a sign saying "I stole mail, this is my punishment," (among other things). The ensuing appeals all were about the constitutionality of humiliation. Ultimately it was decided that shame is permissible if it is an externality of a punishment's goal, it can't be the sole goal.

I'm not trying to defend Justice Thomas, I dont even agree with his opinion there, just trying to say that there are a lot of different angles to getting at this concept of what is "cruel and unusual," . To me, Cali's 3 strikes rule is borderline. And has more to do with theories of punishment than constitutional law, but even that relies on how fluid you think the constitutional ought to be.

Too many moving parts. Thats why we go to school for this shit, I guess.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21368056
>>21368316
>>21368471
It's quite interesting actually and I happen to know a fair bit about the specific topic. Thomas and Scalia both believe the 8th Amendment has no guarantee of proportionality, which is at odds with pretty much everyone else on the Court (other conservative justices like Alito and O'conner reject their arguments; I think O'Conner's plurality opinion in Ewing gives the best argument against Thomas's theory from a somewhat originalist/textualist perspective). There's about a dozen dissenting opinions where Thomas and Scalia cite each other about how the majority is constantly exceeding its authority, which are funny to read, particularly Scalia's.

Thomas actually does think proportionality exists, but is only relevant in capital cases, or (maybe) fines/bail/whippings. Also worth noting that his upper bound for what would be proportionate is something like executing a seven year old for stealing 50 dollars worth of merchandise. Maybe adjusted for inflation if he were feeling particularly generous. The gist of the argument as I understand it is that (a) the framers never used any language to indicate proportionality in sentencing, (b) the 8th Amendment was meant to protect against torture and little else, and (c) prison sentences were never really covered under the 8th Amendment since they didn't exist in 1790; only of relevance is executions, whippings, public shaming, etc. Honestly I might be somewhat incorrect here, but yes, it's exactly as insane as it sounds.

Honestly it's a mediocre argument in my opinion, since the actual text of the 8th Amendment implies proportionality in fines and bail ("excessive" implies proportionality), other historically relevant documents like the English Bill of Rights contain explicit proportionality guarantees, and when dealing with how cruel any punishment is the idea of proportionality is implicit.

Thomas goes over the argument in his dissent in Graham v. Florida. You can ignore everything about how unusual the punishment is (number of states, etc.) since he doesn't think the analysis the majority is using should exist at all, unless you find that debate interesting in its own right.
>https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/560/48/

Do you think that there should be some originalism in (Canadian) constitutional interpretation? I agree with the living tree approach, but it has the potential to theoretically lead to rampant progressivism without the appropriate safeguards. It also gives the Supreme Court a lot of power to justify decisions based on "current Canadian values", which they themselves are empowered to define. No wonder they have rejected originalist thinking outright; they'd be foolish not too desu. Originalism would at least temper outlandish decisions by putting some interpretive restraint on the incredible power they've been enabled to wield.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21375403
>Do you think that there should be some originalism in (Canadian) constitutional interpretation?
No, not really. I generally don't agree with that approach.

>I agree with the living tree approach, but it has the potential to theoretically lead to rampant progressivism without the appropriate safeguards.
I've never met a single judge or lawyer who is particularly progressive, and I've worked for union-side law firms and currently work for a progressive union. The most annoying progressives tend to be people who don't have decision making power. I just don't see rampant progressivism as a real issue that affects the law. Progressivism is more of an imagined threat than a real one.

>It also gives the Supreme Court a lot of power to justify decisions based on "current Canadian values", which they themselves are empowered to define. No wonder they have rejected originalist thinking outright; they'd be foolish not too desu.
I find the SCC treads pretty lightly in that regard, and they have to base it on the evidentiary record from the trial court. I also think that regardless of ideology, smart judges can read whatever they want into the law. Whether it's originalism or living tree, there's a lot of power in the Supreme Court.

>Originalism would at least temper outlandish decisions by putting some interpretive restraint on the incredible power they've been enabled to wield.
I can't name any outlandish progressive SCC decision in recent Canadian history. I find that they are generally very cautious and tend towards being conservative. In general, I see the law as a conservative institution, and I think most Canadian judges treat it that way.

>>21375907
Law isn't easy. People bicker all the time about who should or shouldn't do it. The only thing people agree on is that, even for people with the talent, you gotta try to make it work.

If you wanna do public interest or politics, law is great there. Tons of stuff available. But the main thing is for you to be honest with yourself about how much you jive with the study of law. I picked law over other things cause I can read a case and enjoy reading it, I can't do anything involving math without wanting to die. I get excited talking about law with others, there are a lot of other careers id never do that sort of thing with.

So ask yourself how much you enjoy the study of law. Easiest way, I think, is to study for the LSAT. You'll see how you relate to the sort of thinking Law requires. Or just read a case. Just be honest with yourself :)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Overall, I found nothing unique in Wolfe. Perhaps it's because I've read quite a bit of odd fantasy; if all I read was mainstream stuff, then I'd surely find Wolfe unpredictable, since he is a step above them. But compared to Leiber, Howard, Dunsany, Eddison, Kipling, Haggard, Peake, Mieville, or Moorcock, Wolfe is nothing special.

Perhaps I just got my hopes up too high. I imagined something that might evoke Peake or Leiber (at his best), perhaps with a complexity and depth gesturing toward Milton or Ariosto. I could hardly imagine a better book than that, but even a book half that good would be a delight--or a book that was nothing like that, but was unpredictable and seductive in some other way.

I kept waiting for something to happen, but it never really did. It all plods along without much rise or fall, just the constant moving action to make us think something interesting is happening. I did find some promise, some moments that I would have loved to see the author explore, particularly those odd moments where Silver Age Sci Fi crept in, but each time he touched upon these, he would return immediately to the smallness of his plot and his annoying prick of a narrator. I never found the book to be difficult or complex, merely tiring. the unusual parts were evasive and vague, and the dull parts constant and repetitive.

The whole structure (or lack of it) does leave things up to interpretation, and perhaps that's what some readers find appealing: that they can superimpose their own thoughts and values onto the narrator, and onto the plot itself. But at that point, they don't like the book Wolfe wrote, they like the book they are writing between his lines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21380033
Then there is the fact that every character you meet in the story turns up again, hundreds of miles away, to reveal that they are someone else and have been secretly controlling the action of the plot. It feels like the entire world is populated by about fifteen people who follow the narrator around wherever he goes. If the next two books continue along the same lines, then the big reveal will be that the world is entirely populated by no more than three superpowered shapeshifters.

Everyone in the book has secret identities, secret connections to grand conspiracies, and important plot elements that they conveniently hide until the last minute, only doling out clues here and there. There are no normal people in this world, only double agents and kings in disguise. Every analysis I've read of this book mentions that even the narrator is unreliable.

This can be an effective technique, but in combination with a world of infinite, unpredictable intrigue, Wolfe's story begins to evoke something between a soap opera and a convoluted mystery novel, relying on impossible and contradictory scenarios to mislead the audience. Apparently, this is the thing his fans most appreciate about him--I find it to be an insulting and artificial game.

I agree with this reviewer that there is simply not enough structure to the story to make the narrator's unreliability meaningful. In order for unreliable narration to be effective, there must be some clear and evident counter-story that undermines it. Without that, it is not possible to determine meaning, because there's nowhere to start: everything is equally shaky.

At that point, it's just a trick--adding complexity to the surface of the story without actually producing any new meaning. I know most sci fi and fantasy authors seem to love complexity for its own sake, but it's a cardinal sin of storytelling: don't add something into your story unless it needs to be there. Covering the story with a lot of vagaries and noise may impress some, but won't stand up to careful reading.

>>21363533
quigley is a superb historian who writes excellent prose. there are some lectures and an interview on this website as well >>21363547
read also his "weapons systems and political stability" and "the evolution of civilizations".

the former is a detailed analysis of world history from the beginning of mankind to 1500 AD. it examines the thought-forms and motivations of different civilizations, and the relationship between weaponry and the forms which political systems are able to take. a basic conclusion is that weapon systems which are expensive, and require investment, training, etc. lead to authoritarian political systems (eg. mounted knight and castle => feudalism), while inexpensive, amateur weaponry allows for more democratic systems (eg. hoplite => greek city-state). the book is full of fantastically detailed descriptions of the character and development of the rome, byzantium, islam, china, western europe, russia, and others, and the movements of peoples and their interactions.

the latter work is his causal theory of the macroevolution of civilizations. he posits seven stages of development: (1) mixture, (2) gestation, (3) expansion, (4) conflict, (5) universal empire, (6) decay, (7) invasion. every civilization develops what he calls an "instrument of expansion", which is some organization capable of accumulating a surplus, which can then be invested, allowing for the expansion of the third phase. in mesopotamia this is the priesthood, who understood the cycles of the flood, and collected tithes; in classical civilizations this was slavery; in the west it is various forms of capitalism. the fact that there can be no expansion without surplus (that is, an imbalance), is like the fact that there can be no current in a circuit, without a voltage differential.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
2/2
>>21373621
"instruments" are social organizations intended to serve a particular purpose. for example the military instrument is meant to provide defense and security to the people. eventually however, owing to human weakness, all instruments become "institutions", and the ends for which they were created, become confused with the means by which this was accomplished. "vested interests" insist on maintaining the status quo, and resist reform of these institutions, which would enable them to once again pursue real and helpful ends.
the institutionalization of the instrument of expansion leads to the fourth phase. as the rate of expansion declines, conflict arises between the vested interests, and the rest of society. in an effort to maintain their power and status, the vested interests resort to imperialist wars (as a substitute for intensive expansion), and to squashing class conflicts. if the institution cannot reform, or be circumvented with another instrument of expansion, then the civilization passes into the stage of universal empire. the entire civilization is conquered by one of its peripheral states (eg. rome conquers classical civilization), and rules in a faux and hollow golden age. after this the civilization decays, and eventually is invaded and destroyed.

quigley doesn't buy into any "ancient singular all-powerful atlantean secret society" (and he says as much in an interview). i think he sees things much more like a scientist sees some natural process: as many different small pieces coming together and interacting according to their laws, in order to create some larger emergent phenomenon. the whole process is "inevitable", and is driven by some "daemon of history".
i think that quigley would interpret the conspiracies of the elite in this manner: as the institutionalization of western civilization's instrument of expansion (capitalism), and the attempts by the elite to maintain and extent their own power, against the tide of inevitable decline, and the pressure of reform. this seems to be culminating in a reaction and return to a sort of feudalism, now technological and replacing internalized controls and customs with externalized forms of control. hegelian education systems, psychology, advertising, propaganda, cybernetics, mk ultra, subversion, debt-slavery, goyslop, pornography, homogenization, depopulation, CBDCs, censorship, wokism, social credit systems etc. are all forms of social engineering and attempts to weaken and control an unruly and dangerous mob in an age of conflict. the drive towards universal empire manifests in the global nature of all this action.
it seems unlikely that the west will find a way to reform or circumvent its instrument of expansion. the NWO global beast slavery technocracy may succeed in becoming a universal empire, or a reaction to this may usurp it. either way, western civilization will move closer towards its inevitably dissolution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21380623
No, the 'of' after the comma should be cut. You wouldn't say 'You view of that endless sea of lovers as a toy for your pleasure'; 'endless sea of lovers' is the direct object of 'view' (you would just say 'You view that endless sea ...') so it transforms into the relative pronoun ('whom') without the need for any prepositional padding. If it were acting as an indirect object -- e.g. 'You have nothing to fear from that endless of lovers' -- then you would need hang onto the preposition: 'Disregard that endless sea of lovers, from whom you have nothing to fear.'

posts.sub: Thoughts upon a Split Pee Stream
posts.com:
Happened to me twice the other day, at the toilet and my pee stream split in twain.
Suddenly I remembered my Robert Frost, "Two roads diverged in a yellow wood."
Two streams of urine (two roads), diverging from my weewee (wood).
And I chose the road less traveled by, in choosing to post here, and that has made all the difference.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As I stood at the toilet, I felt a strange sensation. It was as if my urine was being pulled in two different directions, each wanting to go its own way. I watched in amazement as my stream of urine split in twain, creating two separate roads of liquid that flowed effortlessly into the toilet.

At first, I was puzzled by this unusual occurrence. But then, like a bolt of lightning, it struck me. The two roads of urine were a metaphor for the choices we face in life. Just as my urine was divided into two streams, so too are we faced with countless decisions that can take us down vastly different paths.

And just as the streams of urine flowed smoothly and without hesitation, so too must we make our decisions with confidence and determination. For if we hesitate, or try to merge the two streams back together, we risk confusion and chaos.

But despite the potential pitfalls, the beauty of these two roads lies in their ability to offer us endless possibilities. Just as my urine flowed freely and without restraint, so too can our lives be filled with adventure and excitement if we are willing to take risks and embrace the unknown.

And so, as I flushed the toilet and went on with my day, I couldn't help but be reminded of the power of choice and the endless opportunities that lay before us. For just as my urine had flowed down two distinct paths, so too can our lives be filled with endless possibilities if we are brave enough to embrace them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As I sat upon the porcelain throne, my gaze drifting aimlessly across the bathroom, I was suddenly struck by the realization that my stream of urine was no longer a singular flow, but had split into two distinct paths. The sensation was both surprising and perplexing, and I couldn't help but be reminded of the famous line from Robert Frost's poem, "The Road Not Taken": "Two roads diverged in a yellow wood."

Just as Frost's narrator stands at the fork in the road, uncertain of which path to take, I too was faced with a dilemma. The twin streams of urine diverging from my nether regions seemed to symbolize the choices that lay before me, and I couldn't help but wonder which path was the right one to take.

But unlike Frost's character, I did not have the luxury of choosing which path to take. No, my body had made the decision for me, and I was left to ponder the meaning of this strange occurrence. Why had my stream split in twain? Was it a sign of some underlying health issue? Or was it simply a quirky, random event that held no deeper significance?

As I sat there, I found myself unable to come to a conclusion. Instead, I was overcome with a sense of absurdity, a feeling that the whole situation was inherently ridiculous. Here I was, a grown man, pondering the meaning of a split stream of urine. It was a moment of levity in an otherwise serious and ponderous day. In the end, I couldn't help but laugh at myself, and the absurdity of the whole situation. And as I flushed the toilet and went on with my day, I couldn't help but feel grateful for this strange dream-like experience.

I have the sense that there's tons of cultural history books on commodities and consumerism -- but sadly I don't know any of them.

I know Roland Barthes (forget where) and John Berger (in Ways of Seeing) both talk about 17th-century Dutch still life painting as a product of an early stage of consumerism, presenting these realistic, tactile objects arrayed for you to survey and desire and possess.

Maybe this doesn't totally get Benjamin's method. He obviously thinks there's something unique about the arcades, but soulfulness is always retrospective and just-disappeared, so it's not a substance that one era has and another doesn't but rather the secret underside of one era that is suddenly glimpsed in a new, fleeting light from the perspective of its successor. I am sure another Benjamin could have written a '50s Supermarket Project, or a '80s Mall Project.

This is actually a great collection. Highly recommended, OP. It covers all the basis you’re looking for.

Also, in order to understand consumerism you MUST understand the advertising industry. Read Roland Marchand’s Advertising the American Dream, and TJ Lears’ Fables of Abundance. If you’re interested in the history of childhood consumerism and how (((they))) get you young, read the Commodification of Childhood by Daniel Thomas Cooke, and Kids’ Stuff by Gary Cross

For an accessible overview of 20th century consoomerism, check out Gary Cross’s The All Consuming Century: How Commercialism Won in America.

To understand the creation of a distinct consoomer class and ideology, see Lizabeth Cohen’s A Consumer’s Republic.

And as the anon above said, Baudrillard’s going to be your main reference for the philosophy of consumerism. Start with Consumer Society— it’s much more accessible than his other works.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21375421
>>21375660
Also, I see you mentioned shopping malls. A great work on the philosophy of places like this is Marc Augue’s Non-Places: an introduction to super-modernity. He argues that places like airports and malls have become utterly devoid of the characteristics that define an anthropological place (community, togetherness, familial ties, cultural history, etc). Instead, he argues, these types of places have simply become liminal spaces constructed in order to fulfill the needs of consumers. The physical location itself has superseded the symbolic attachments we have to traditional places. Instead, these non-places serve as simple transitional spaces from one act of consumption to the next, utterly devoid of any meaning beyond their own purpose. I need to read it again, but I think the current Zoomer fascination with liminal spaces and the back rooms are a result of this concept.

This anon has rec'd several of the books I would've. Listen to this poster OP because it's a superb answer.

The only thing I'd add are some recommendations:

>Find a good definition of consumerism in the academic literature
This will probably seem pedantic but having a definition would help you immensely. In these collections there's such a multitude of perspectives that it's easy to get lost; having a provisional definition works like a border of a jigsaw puzzle: you can slot new knowledge in easier.

>Find some annotated bibliographies
Go onto Oxford Bibliographies and search consumerism and other related terms. Most of the books won't be relevant. But you'd find some obscure stuff there.

>Read from a variety of perspectives
Don't overload yourself with Marxist perspectives. I find them the most convincing and useful, though you should try to attack this from several angles. The best thing to do would even be to shift through INDUSTRY publications!

>Engage with content outside the academic literature
Try to engage with some kids movies, TV shows and novels about consumerism. Anything that has it as a theme. You can't rely on books to do your thinking for you and this is a good way to see what critiques are laying dormant.

Good luck with your project! The only book I'd recommend is Sianne Ngai's Theory of the Gimmick -- just be warned that it's challenging

>>21375421
If you want to go deven father back, take a look at TH Breen's The Marketplace of Revolution: How Consumer Politics Shaped American Independence.

This work honestly reshaped much of the scholarship surrounding the American Revolution. It's kind of dense, definitely not the must interesting read at times, but he lays out a pretty convincing argument.

Colonial American's enjoyed living and consooming in a trans-Atlantic world full of new consumer goods. 18th-century Britain was laying the foundation for the Industrial Revolution, especially in the hinterlands where individual households produced what Breen calls the "baubles" of Britain. These shiny trinkets filled genteel and middle class colonists' homes.
As the American independence movement began, the levies on consumer goods increased. This caused the vast majority of Americans-- even those who didn't give a shit about the high minded Enlightenment ideals-- to seethe to unprecedented levels. Once their consooooming was interrupted, more colonists participated in revolutionary politics in greater numbers and with a newfound fervor. Aditionally, Breen argues much of the early networks of communication (committees of correspondence) and demonstrates centered around protests against taxes that negatively impacted consumers the most (must... consoom.... MUH TEA... need... LE PLAYING CARDS).
Boycotts and similar protests allowed all colonists to participate in the revolution. Women especially found a sense of patriotisms in their shopping choices. Women often controlled most of the household budget, and their correspondence helped further strengthen ties throughout the colonies.

The story is nothing new: no taxation without representation (retarded argument btw). Breen's contribution was that it was precisely the consooming American public that formed the basis for revolutionary change.
As he argues:
>the colonists' shared experience as consumers provided them with cultural resources needed to develop a bold new form of political protest. In this unprecedented context, private decisions were interpreted as political acts; consumer choices communicated personal loyalties. Goods became the foundation of trust, for one's willingness to sacrifice the pleasures of the market provided as remarkably visible and effective test of allegiance.

I think it's an important work if you want to study the development of American consumer behavior and the politics of consumption. It also shows that mutts will put up with whatever until their precious product is threatend or unavailable.

If you don't want to read the full book, just check out Breen's article here: https://www.jstor.org/stable/651021

Advertisers certainly push the BUY NEW AND BETTER EVEN THOUGH YOUR CURRENT ITERATION OF THE PRODUCT IS PERFECTLY FINE (this is a huge reason the American automobile industry tanked in the ‘60s). What I think this anon is talking about is the advertisers’ ability to read consumer trends and the culture at large, always dangling a new product that serves not just as a product, but a key component in building an identity. They keep the consumer constantly on edge, eager not to miss out on the latest trend which allows them to more fully participate in whatever community they wish to associate themselves with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21380217
That's precisely what I mean. The problem is that aesthetic objects - or subcultures, sure - is that they often lapse into irony, self-criticism and satire before declining. This final ironic flash can keep the lights on as interest begins to fade, like violently squeezing the last bit of toothpaste out of the container. Is it intended to be used that way? Probably not, but you always get more out of it than you expect. r/circlejerks can keep the spirit alive months after the thing itself has been exhausted.

At any rate, I'm interested in sellers anticipating this bitter winter-y decline and selling the consumers dissatisfaction back to them. In this sense the consumer is both affirming and negating the product. More importantly though they remain in the ecosystem. They stay consumers.

I'm sure this is address is one of the books already posted, but if there's any work on the etymology of consumption and how this word (and related key-words) have shifted, both over time and cross-culturally, I'd appreciate it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21380320
Should've just googled: there's an article by David Graeber on this, "Consumption."

>Beginning in the 1980s, anthropologists began to be bombarded with endless—and often strangely moralistic—exhortations to acknowledge the importance of something referred to as “consumption.” The exhortations were effective; for the past 2 decades, the term has become a staple of theoretical discourse. Rarely, however, do anthropologists examine it: asking themselves why it is that almost all forms of human self-expression or enjoyment are now being seen as analogous to eating food. This essay seeks to investigate how this came about, beginning with medieval European theories of desire and culminating in the argument that the notion of consumption ultimately resolves certain conceptual problems in possessive individualism.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21380007
It's not so hard to imagine an alternative way to live. A lot of men do this on the daily. You don't even need to push the clock back any further than a hundred years.
Your issue isn't even with consumerism as an aspect of life; you consume media, you consume propaganda, you consume ideology, and your existence itself is built upon a pillar of constant consumption for subsistence. That's not the problem here.
The problem is, and always has been, that consumerism pertains to a type of collective neurosis in which you're bombarded by a culture and shit you don't need. Where everything is out to get you like you were a goddamned schizophrenic, because ultimately you're nothing more than a source of profit. This is the real issue, this hyperreal and completely fucking batshit capitalism that prompts you to recoil in this way. Under these lenses, sure, it's hard to imagine an alternative...until you begin giving purpose to your actions and your possessions. It's as simple as keeping things grounded and practical: don't seek what you don't need, don't engage with what you feel doesn't belong in your life, listen to Marie fucking Kondo and you'll be a happy camper. Give structure to your material goods and your consumption and find a fucking center of gravity to balance yourself upon. This was normal before advertising really took off. This was - and will always be - humanity's only real materialistic philosophy, it's why even when the world tells you otherwise you seek this type of life out, and why after stumbling enough in the dark we'll find our way back to it.

>Alfred Edward Housman (26 March 1859 – 30 April 1936) was an English classical scholar and poet. His cycle of poems, A Shropshire Lad, wistfully evokes the constraints and limited choices of youth in the English countryside. The simplicity and distinctive imagery of the writing appealed strongly to Edwardian taste, and to many early 20th-century English composers, both before and after the First World War. Through their song-settings, the poems became closely associated with that era, and with Shropshire itself.
>Housman was one of the foremost classicists of his age and has been ranked as one of the greatest scholars at any time. He established his reputation publishing as a private scholar at first and, on the strength and quality of his work, was appointed Professor of Latin at University College London and then at the University of Cambridge. His editions of Juvenal, Manilius and Lucan are still considered authoritative.

During the years when I earned my living as a teacher of fiction-writing in a university, one or another of my students would sometimes call on me in my office and would claim that she could not write the pieces of fiction that I required her to write and would give as the reason for this that she did not understand what I meant by the word fiction. I used the words her and she in the previous sentence only because three-quarters of my students of fiction-writing were females.

While I was writing the previous sentence, I saw in my mind an image of the view from the chair that I used as my chair in one of the rooms that I used as my office during the years when I was a teacher in a university. The view was of part of the room as it would have appeared to me if ever I had been visited in my office by a certain young woman who was one of my students for two years but never visited me during those years. The young woman never visited me or asked me to explain what I meant by the word fiction, but she wrote as the last of her assignments while she was my student a piece of fiction that earned from me the highest numerical mark on a scale of 1 to 100 that I gave to any piece of fiction during the years mentioned above.

While I was writing the previous paragraph, I understood that the young woman mentioned there was listening to the words of a man who was talking about the writing of fiction. I could not see any image of the man, and I could not hear in my mind any words that the man was speaking, but I understood that the man was in the room and that the young woman was listening to the words of the man. I understood these things in the same way that I understand many of the matters that I seem afterwards to have seen and to have heard while dreaming.

While I was writing the previous paragraph, I understood that the young woman mentioned there could not hear any words from the man mentioned there but that she was aware of what the man could well have spoken to her in the same way that I am aware of what could well have been spoken to me by images of persons that I seem afterwards to have been aware of while dreaming.

posts.name: Bookie
posts.com:
>>21374627
To get into writing poetry, you must get into reading and thinking about poetry. But do not take this to mean that you cannot write until you have read, instead you should constantly be attempting to write. You can start out doing experiments like those of Charles Bernstein (https://writing.upenn.edu/bernstein/experiments.html), or just write responses to things you've read, seen or heard. Try writing down your thoughts as prose and arranging them into poetry. One of the biggest mistakes you can make is valuing reading poetry over writing it. Do not read so much poetry that you become marinated in it. Start by finding out just two or three poets you really like, and read them. And then you can start adding more to that list as you write more.

How the fuck do you become good at writing? I don't even like most published books I read. How do you know whose feedback to trust?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: you can practice for decades and never become good at writing. there are no functional rules, and there is no way to teach an individual the skills necessary to create a literary masterpiece. other crafts are different because you're not comparing like with like. broaden the given craft to its origin, and you'll see that it functions much the same as an open-ended repository for the individual's pursuit of an ideal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21378140
>broaden the given craft to its origin, and you'll see that it functions much the same as an open-ended repository for the individual's pursuit of an ideal.
can you expand on this anon

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21378151
in my naive opinion, that is what art is fundamentally. the manifestation of the individual's pursuit of the ideal. the closer one comes to realizing the ideal, the better the art (usually). think of the art as a byproduct, instead of the goal, and you'll start to understand what i mean. A person looks to simply comprehend a thing, (anything from a glass of water to the concept of love itself is a valid pursued ideal) and in so doing, they leave a sort of husk of their transformed selves or their environments in the process of refining that ideal. it's the only definition i've ever felt is open enough to describe art in the grand sense, since anything from someone gyrating their hips to a sequence of unrecorded thought can and has been considered art.

I'd say read, a fucking lot, then narrow down what medium are you aiming, each has its own distinctive style and purpose, so sort together if you're doing a novel or a screenwriting for example.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21378151
also, to explain broadening the craft, take sculpture, or painting, you cannot properly compare those to something like literature as a whole. you'd have to compare literature to the visual medium of art (which arguably includes literature, amusingly, since it's just a collection of symbols) before you were comparing apples to apples. most of the foundational genres are this way, nigh infinite, only limited by the individual and their ability.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21378106
Read a ton, really aim at making your daily life about reading and rereading just like one would watch a series over and over for comfort.
While doing that- just write. Your personal voice and flair will come out, don't force yourself into genres you can't write; I believe every author has a style and genre they belong to, and there is numerous examples when one tries to break out of it and ends up with a bad piece of work. Don't rely on feedback- be your own feedback. It's gotta feel right, it's gotta flow well in your head, and your volume of work needs to be massive too. Writing and begging for feedback at every step is a cuckold move and shows that one is writing for personal gratification and affirmation of their ego and NOT for the simple pleasure that one derives from being a wordcel.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21378223
>Writing and begging for feedback at every step is a cuckold move and shows that one is writing for personal gratification and affirmation of their ego and NOT for the simple pleasure that one derives from being a wordcel.
I understand what you're saying here, that you should enjoy the process of writing in itself -- but that aside, isn't regular feedback extremely important for improving your craft? Don't you need critique in all skilled crafts to improve?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21378223
>Writing and begging for feedback at every step is a cuckold move and shows that one is writing for personal gratification and affirmation of their ego and NOT for the simple pleasure that one derives from being a wordcel.

I think that's important. You'll never really feel validated either, because that cycle just repeats. You need to have your own standards and tastes or some sort of 'goal' or metric by wish to measure success and shoot for that.
I think eventually there will be a time to share the work and find someone who will be able to understand what you have tried to do and will be equipped to judge it with your goals in mind, but that is potentially far down the road.
That said I also think the idea of the lone genius hammering at his soul in isolation is a bit of a myth too and doesn't need to be the only way. History is full of writing groups. The key is just to have a group of likeminded people of similar abilities who have sympathy for the goals and sensibilities of the other people in the group and don't need to push their own ways and egos onto others, which can be damaging and limiting, for both the one giving the advice and the one receiving it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21378106
>Seriously, how do you git gud?
You have to have an internal conception of what gud is. It has to be intuitive, otherwise you will inevitably find yourself broken to The Rules, as written by people who have otherwise never written anything of note. Another anon has had good ideas with which I don't disagree, but in addition I want to stress that, in my opinion, analysis has never once created an amazing writer despite centuries of ongoing academic effort. Analysis certainly manages to coexist in the mindscapes of (some of) the greats, but it is not necessary. I don't think it even helps, personally, at least not once you let go of your independence of thought, subsume your individualism and start seeing literally anyone as "more expert" than you are. Good writing is, in my opinion, a function primarily of good taste and dedicated practice. The things you like about literature should be deep and enduring love for inexpressible infinitesimals you (and maybe only you) find exhilarating. The things you dislike about literature should be deep and burning hatreds. Above all, you should trust your ability to (eventually) grasp that for which you reach. Be both your own biggest cheerleader and harshest critic when necessary, and recognize that writing something that didn't work does not mean that you will never write something that does. We are all eternal students to no teacher but the act of writing

I like all of this, in various ways. I am not a good writer. I try. I fail on fundamental levels. I write every day; thousands of words. Sometimes it is okay. I find myself aware of a feeling, and it is almost as though when I write I need to get that feeling, or else I did not write well. It is flow, I suppose, to use the shorthand term, though I am not sure I entirely agree with all of that concept.
Curiosity is very important though, I am finding. If I am not curious for what I write, it is not living, and I have to see it or hear it too as I write it, not before I write it, but AS I write it. And I need to dig at it, the images and scenes and everything, words. What's this or that, why did I use that word or event, where's that going? When I have no curiosity, it is dead. Many days it is dead, yet I sit and I type anyway.

As I said I am not a good writer. It may make me sound retarded but I have not found the way to revise my work or edit it. I just write. If I write an entire story in a day, good. If it is fragments, okay. I have concepts and characters I return to, but I write in fragments that contradict each other. It is all a mess with no cohesion. To complete it, revise it, edit it, make it shine. That's where I am struggling to go.

I also wonder if my idea of what I look for, that feeling, that flow, is not merely another limitation I've taken on that shackles me somehow. There are many traps. You just have to do it though. There's no understanding without doing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21378471
I would also like to say that my pursuit of writing, seriously, has changed my life. My mind has shifted from what it was, or what I thought it was. The anon who said writing is a by-product, or should be seen as such, I think had a good idea. Annie Dillard said it similarly: aim for the chopping block, not the wood (this is a wood chopping analogy). Andre Gide said his writing was something like, to paraphrase, the pursuit of his soul, or the growth of his soul. That's good too. With writing seriously I've found that I could never write before due to faults in my own character, or views, or mindset, or state of mind. I had to shift my whole world around to even get myself to sit down each day and write for a few hours. And now I've mastered sitting and typing I find myself blocked with how to return to revise a story, or edit it, and actually make it whole and complete (or as much as can be). And of course with just returning at will to write something, because most days I feel completely thrown about by outside forces that I have to follow or simply waste the day and go limp. I imagine my world is going to have to shift again in order to facilitate these goals, though I have no idea how. One might think it is very simple, point here, do that, make a list, organise, make a plot, follow it, but in practice I find it deeply involved, as though it's all different ways of seeing and being, so getting myself to that place where I can sit on the level I desire and have it all work . . . well that's blocked to me somehow now.

>>21377553
>Good book for someone based into catholicism

Highly recommend Louis Bouyer, The Bible and the Gospel: The Meaning of Scripture

Or: Bouyer, The Spirit and Forms of Protestantism, which is somewhat well known because many converts to Catholicism were influenced by it (eg, Scott Hahn).

Both books, written in the 1950s, are excellent. Bouyer was a world-class scholar and a very good writer. If your friend reads the Bible a lot, he might get more from the first book. I don't know of a better short introduction to the Old Testament, and in particular how the gradual revelation of the nature of God prepared the way for the coming of Christ, whom Bouyer shows, very clearly, was the inevitable and necessary fulfillment of so many different strands of OT history and belief.

>>21373688
The Traditionalist critique of Christianity is that it's a merely sentimental/moral religion, that the highest one can achieve within it is a vague mystical state (as Evola says, merely ecstatic and passive, without post-ecstatic and active "re-entry" into one's self, completing the self-conscious initiation process), and also that ANY AND ALL historical and eschatological events or revelations (like God giving his unique revelation to Moses, and later Christ's redemption, but also the ongoing fight against Satan's influence in this world) are inadmissible from a Traditional standpoint - because history means nothing from the Traditional standpoint, which is anti-eschatological, regarding eschatologies as particularist and exclusivist tribal myths that have become dogmas. Essentially, Traditionalism's critique of Christianity is very similar to the Theravada critique of Mahayana Buddhism's soteriological and eschatological elements.

But these criticisms potentially force Traditionalism itself into a passive and quietistic position, which it is supposedly criticizing Christianity for. If there is no collective mystery or collective quest for redemption or struggle against Satan, if religions can't have an eschatological, soteriological, world historical character, because the only real truth lies in the universal metaphysical truth attained through individual initiation, then why bother fighting the occult war at all? In fact this is where a lot of Guenonians end up, advocating just riding out the kali yuga because it's all cyclical anyway. If your conception of all human dealings, all history, is simply that it is samsara, with no teleological or eschatology, then your only two options for understanding samsara are (1) it's an uncreated and "static" eternal world, like Aristotle's world, or (2) it cyclically dies and is reborn, and presumably there is some symbolically "fixed" number and nature to the ages of the cycle and so on and so forth, but again all this means nothing, since as an individual initiate you cannot affect the cycles in any way, or perhaps at most you can accelerate the present one (?).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21373691
What is even the value in seeking to create a "diamond/rainbow body" and escape samsara at all? Why seek immortality? Why desire to order society according to divine models if it's all cyclical or indifferent anyway? Guenon and Evola both emphasize that there is nothing "moral" in what they are doing, and that the vulgar sentimental and moral religion of everyday faithful is merely exoteric, basically its only value is containing dumbed down versions of symbols that keep ordinary people anchored in their Traditional-Platonic republics, while maintaining pathways of symbolic ascent for talented individuals to pursue to their eventual initiation. But again, why? Unless there is some real, non-cylical, zero-sum struggle going on, then who cares? Why do things even happen contingently in history, like Evola says when he says that it's bizarre that such a sentimental religion took hold in the "active" West, if everything is cyclical?

It seems to me like there are contradictions in the Traditionalist worldview, because it wants to take history seriously, it wants to take the occult war seriously, it wants to be active in the world (except for some extreme Guenonians), it has or wants to have an eschatology, but it can't admit this to itself because it views all of these things as inadmissible in pure metaphysics. It's a bit like modern science in this way: science is unwilling to envision anything metaphysical, because it's obsessed with not tainting itself with superstitions. Similarly Traditionalism doesn't want to taint itself with mere samsaric, dogmatic, sentimental, tribal superstitions. But just like modern science closes itself off to genuine truths and opportunities, Traditionalism closes itself off to non-jnana possibilities that are more interesting than it imagines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21373693
For example, it closes itself off to angelology and demonology, to the idea that on higher metaphysical planes there are beings beyond the human (at least in part) who are both good and evil. Ironically it ends up "confusing the planes" itself, by assuming that the only thing between man and the Absolute is this metaphysical hierarchy of symbols, and that there are no other beings with plans for us, that the cosmos is a cyclically autorenewing stage on which a few Guenons and Evolas periodically become immortal (for what? where do they go? if it's just to a purified paradisiacal state, isn't that what they criticize Christianity for promising?). Most major traditions have some form of angelology/demonology, whether Neoplatonic or Christian, pre-Islamic djinn, Buddhist demonology, etc. From a Traditionalist perspective, a Christian or Neoplatonic angelology that emphasizes faith in and collaboration with Good beings who are actively engaged in an eschatological fight, an occult war, and who both want to help us and who want our help, would just be superstition. But from a Christian perspective, and from a Neoplatonic or even Mahayana perspective that takes the occult war seriously, Traditionalism would be dangerously "magical" in trying to be an amoral series of techniques, and advice for the maintenance of said techniques in initiatic lines, in a cosmos in which active participation in soteriological eschatology is a necessary element of any awakening, and in which demonic forces are equally active. From this perspective, Evola and Guenon would be doing exactly what they criticize New Agers for doing: stripping people of their everyday protections and throwing them into trans-personal psychic experiences in which they will simply be subject to whatever forces are nearby.

In rejecting all claims to revelation as contingent and samsaric, Traditionalism also misses out on the possibility of a symbolic interpretation of "dispensationalist" revelation, in which history is not merely samsaric and cyclical, and attaining enlightenment is not merely optional and always potentially open to amoral initiates, and the occult war is not merely a particularly bad patch in the most recent kali yuga in an infinite cycle of them, but instead, history is not cylical, there is a fixed goal here, there are win and lose conditions, enlightenment is not just "available" to initiates but is a responsibility and a duty, and thus enabling others to be enlightened is also a duty, etc.

>>21373697
And therefore, the mythic-eschatological content of a religion like Christianity, with its publically available emphasis on resisting Satan and imitating Christ in daily life, is not just an incidental exoteric form of symbols that are only really relevant to autistic initiates, there is actually a purpose to the "opening" of the mysteries, which, yes, vulgarized them from a certain perspective, but perhaps only because this was analogous to sprinkling thousands of seeds, formerly been contained in neatly condensed form in individual pots, over a huge field of soil and manure, so that at first they seem merely "lost," but in time they grow and become many thousands of fruit-bearing, seed-bearing trees themselves?

If all of history can be interpreted symbolically in this way, then we can begin to ask questions that the Traditionalists are afraid to ask: What does it MEAN, using symbolic interpretation and sympathetic intuition, that Christ figures appeared and managed to embed moral messages and fundamentally change history, turning pagan Europe into a moral and even sentimental Christian Europe - which Evola can only view as an aberration, from his Traditionalist perspective? What does it MEAN that analogous developments occurred in India, with Mahayana and other soteriological movements introducing new ideas into the stagnant and formalistic ritualistic cults? If this is all just samsaric "noise," (1) why would there be any "noise" that diverges from the cyclical norm, and (2) why care at all? It's just a blip in the cycle.

Traditionalist metaphysics in my view also has an impoverished account of metaphysical personality and of the metaphysics of freedom, but I've already written too much, sorry about that. But I find the dismissal of the encounter of personal beings in mystical states incomplete and even lazy. The "scientific" starkness of Traditionalism is very useful insofar as it burns away all the dangerous dross of, for example, Blavatsky's Theosophy's blind faith in its Masters of Wisdom, or Steiner's endless visionary claims with no proof. But it should have been a clearing and a praeparatio evangelica, not a self-sufficient technique to end all techniques. Overall I think Traditionalism needs a re-fertilization by all the traditions it rejects: Abrahamic, Zoroastrian, and Hindu bhakti. Its extreme rejection of personal, moral, eschatological, and soteriological elements was historically conditioned by the dangerous spread of New Age syncretism and occultism that led to people like Crowley (probably genuinely dangerous, as can be seen in Scientology). This process should be oriented toward fighting the occult war in a moral, soteriological, eschatological way. The presupposition of autistic initiation and meaningless cyclical samsara should be dropped, and the "merely accidental" elements of traditions (that is, that don't accord with autistic initiation and meaningless cyclicality) should be reinterpreted in this light.

>>21373703

This ties into the poverty of the Traditionalist understanding of personality and freedom: they only see these as sources or vehicles of contingency, to be purged so that the higher self can be brought forth, transcending contingency and leaving samsara. But personality and freedom are symbolically analogous to history: apparent contingency that can contain or reflect symbolic truth. Traditionalism sees all three of these categories in a merely negative way, each is interpreted as mere caprice or as the negative pole of manifestation of essence. But if the nature of all being is that of essence, which is pure in itself but which struggles to manifest clearly in becoming, then why shouldn't becoming itself (and its subordinate aspects: personality, freedom, history) have its own essence and meaning? Why not interpret ALL temporal contingency, all becoming qua "mere negation of, or derivation or divagation from, atemporal being," as itself the symbolic emanation of an essence that combines and explains both being and becoming, instead of merely LEAVING becoming as an empty/negative category as almost all nondualist metaphysicians, including Traditionalists, do? This inquiry would allow us to ask all the questions Traditionalists can't ask from within their own framework:
>Why does samsara/maya (the totality of Becoming as the mirror of the totality of Being) exist at all?
>Why do individual Persons (individual monads of Becoming, strung between equal possibilities of self-distancing from Being or self-purification and ascent to Being, undecidable except by the individual Person) exist at all, as distinct from the spheres of emanation?
>Why do individual souls perceive themselves as free (the right to Become Being, or not to Become non-Being, undecidable except by the Person)?
>What is the nature of non-human souls (monads of Becoming with higher grades of Being)?
>What is the nature of God (the Being that mirrors itself in Becoming), and why is Free Personality (the right to Become etc.) among the elements that stems from God, if it has no Being and no meaning?
while using the Traditionalists' refined methods of sympathetic symbolic intuition, just training it on the one symbol they most neglect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21365895
Let me explain. "She sat the chair" doesn't work no matter how much you try to make it work because "sat" is intransitive, you don't sit something, you simply sit. You can say "I sat" or "I sat [on] the chair", since "on" is a preposition, but you cannot say "I sat the chair".
"I sing the body electric" sounds unusual, but is perfectly valid grammar, since sing can be used transitively (as in "I sing a song", "the body" is just an unusual noun to pair with it). "Electric" is an adjective and is modifying the subject. You are allowed to end a sentence with an adjective, it's just uncommonly used with that specific combination of words.
I'm half convinced nobody on this board actually knows English.

posts.com:
So I've been workshopping this magic system for my novel for about six years now as worldbuilding. I haven't figured out any of the story, characters, themes, or message yet, but my worldbuilding and magic system have been coming along for a while (I have a full three pages in Word).

In my world, your magic meter is based on how much urine is in your bladder. The power of magic comes from urine, so the more you can retain in your body the more magic you can perform and the more powerful the magic is. This means that characters need to train their bladders to hold more and more urine, and before a big fight they drink lots of water to stock up on magic meter. The balance to this is that the more powerful a magic user you are, the more urgently you need to finish a battle and use your magic, because you really need to pee. Most battles involve characters dancing around and holding in their pee excruciatingly.

I'm hoping this can really grip readers and be a relatable system for magic use that gives tangible stakes. I've spent a long time on this, so I think people will really like it. I've got a sample below to show it:

Yorindu had to pee really bad, and that was good because his magic comes from pee. The more pee he could hold in, the greater his sorcery would grow. He was practicing his magic by sitting in one place and squirming. In the land of Per'du'mahyo'wank'do the only way to do magic was not peeing. An empty bladder was a death sentence. Today his piss magic was overflowing and his kidneys were at a dangerous risk, his bladder was almost bursting. He was ready for battle with the dark lord, who had the biggest bladder in the land. It would be an almost impossible battle, as his bladder could hold only 3 cups of urine, which for a human was quite a lot, but the dark lord's bladder could hold over 20 cups of urine! His magic level was far higher, but the power of friendship could perhaps unite the urine of he and his friends.

What do you think?

>>21365241
I’ve been there. It’s like mental constipation, but you have to do it anyway. Even when it’s the biggest chore, force yourself to sit down and do it. Grab your coffee or your tea. Open your word processor, and whatever notes you use if you have them, and force yourself to edit, making a roadmap of things to do in a Google doc if you need to.

Creativity responds to discipline, you have to train it. It’s like going to the gym. One day you’re bench pressing 200 no problem, then you stop going for a month or two, and suddenly doing 150 feels impossible.

Once you get into the routine again, it will smooth out. The hardest part is brute forcing through that first week. It’s like quitting smoking.

Turn off your phone and any distractions when you sit down to edit, and set a timer for two hours. Don’t let yourself do anything else except look at the screen and work for the whole two hours until the timer goes off.

Even still, you won’t get much work done. When I was in your shoes I went from writing a few thousands words a day to a couple hundred a day when I tried to get back on track, but after a week or two of forcing my way through it got easier and more natural, and now I’m back at my peak performance again.

But you have to do it EVERY DAY for a week or two. If you do it for one day then take another hiatus, you’re just slipping back down the writer’s block slide. Forge on through that first week or two of mental agony and then things get easier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I recommend that everyone in this thread check out the essay 'The Sentence is a Lonely Place', by Gary Lutz: https://culture.org/the-sentence-is-a-lonely-place/

It really zooms in on the micro-level of the sentence, and how putting ideas and images into the alien element of language means being sensitive to the autonomous way that that element generates new associations and patterns.

>As a reader, I finally knew what I wanted to read, and as someone now yearning to become a writer, I knew exactly what I wanted to try to write: [...] I favored books that you could open to any page and find in every paragraph sentences that had been worked and reworked until their forms and contours and their organizations of sound had about them an air of having been foreordained—as if this combination of words could not be improved upon and had finished readying itself for infinity.

>[...] As you situate the words, you are of course intent on obeying the ordinances of syntax and grammar, unless any willful violation is your purpose—and you are intent as well on achieving in the arrangements of words as much fidelity as is possible to whatever you believe you have wanted to say or describe. A lot of writers—many of them—unfortunately seem to stop there. [...] But some other writers seem to know that it takes more than that for a sentence to cohere and flourish as a work of art. They seem to know that the words inside the sentence must behave as if they were destined to belong together—as if their separation from each other would deprive the parent story or novel, as well as the readerly world, of something life-bearing and essential. These writers recognize that there needs to be an intimacy between the words, a togetherness that has nothing to do with grammar or syntax but instead has to do with the very shapes and sounds, the forms and contours, of the gathered words.

>[...] This kind of flirtation between two letters and their eventual matrimony brighten Christine Schutt’s work not only in the individual sentence but in the paragraph as well. In the four-sentence opening paragraph of the story “The Summer after Barbara Claffey,” [...] the characters k and w spend the first three sentences dancing around each other and sometimes tentatively touching, but their intimacy never gets more serious than the conventional embrace they entertain in the familiar participle walking: "I once saw a man hook a walking stick around a woman’s neck. This was at night, from my mother’s window. The man dropped the crooked end behind the woman’s neck and yanked just hard enough to get the woman walking to the car."
